column1: A heart positron emission tomography (PET) scan is an imaging test that uses a radioactive substance called a tracer to look for disease or poor blood flow in the heart.

Unlike magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and computed tomography (CT), which reveal the structure of and blood flow to and from organs, a PET scan gives more information about how organs and tissues are working.

A heart PET scan can detect whether areas of your heart muscle are receiving enough blood, if there is heart damage or scar tissue in the heart, or if there is a build up of abnormal substances in the heart muscle.
- This tracer is given through a vein (IV), most often on the inside of your elbow.
- Electrodes for an electrocardiogram (ECG) will be placed on your chest.
You must lie still during the PET scan so that the machine can produce clear images of your heart.
A PET scan causes no pain.
Some people have pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site.
Blood sugar or insulin levels may affect the test results in people with diabetes.
Most PET scans are now performed along with a CT scan.
